message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including speech delay, poor eye contact, and macroorchidism (enlarged testicles), suggest Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by an expansion of CGG trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene. None of the other answer choices are associated with Fragile X syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of delayed language development, disinterest, and poor eye contact along with physical examination findings of a prominent jaw, single palmar crease, and enlarged testicles suggest fragile X syndrome. The most common cause of fragile X syndrome is an expansion of CGG trinucleotide repeats in the FMR1 gene. Thus, the correct answer is (A).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination findings, including a single palmar crease and bilaterally enlarged testicles, are consistent with fragile X syndrome, which is caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion. This genetic mutation can lead to intellectual disability, delayed speech and language development, and other developmental symptoms.Microdeletions of chromosome 5 and 7 are not associated with fragile X syndrome. CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion is associated with myotonic dystrophy, which is not consistent with the patient’s symptomatology.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms align with Fragile X Syndrome, which is caused by an expansion of the CGG trinucleotide repeat. The prominent jaw, single palmar crease, and enlarged testicles are physical manifestations of the syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of poor eye contact, developmental delay, and bilateral testicular enlargement are consistent with Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the Fragile X mental retardation 1 (FMR1) gene. The single palmar crease is a common finding in individuals with Down syndrome, which is caused by a microdeletion of the long arm of chromosome 21. None of the other options are associated with the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests fragile X syndrome, which is caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion. The enlarged testicles are a common finding in males with this syndrome. The other answer choices are associated with different genetic disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion. The prominent jaw, single palmar crease, and bilaterally enlarged testicles are all associated with this syndrome. None of the other options are associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination are consistent with Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome. It is the most common cause of inherited intellectual disability. The other options are associated with different genetic disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by an expansion of the CGG trinucleotide repeat. The enlarged testicles are a common finding in males with this condition. Microdeletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 is associated with Cri-du-chat syndrome, which presents with a high-pitched cat-like cry as well as developmental and intellectual disabilities. Microdeletion of the long arm of chromosome 7 is associated with Williams syndrome, which presents with mild to moderate intellectual disability as well as distinctive facial features and cardiovascular abnormalities. CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion is associated with myotonic dystrophy, which presents with muscle weakness and wasting as well as intellectual disability, but not the specific developmental delays described in the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presented symptoms suggest Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion on the X chromosome. The prominent jaw, single palmar crease, and enlarged testicles further support this diagnosis. None of the other answer options match the symptoms presented in the question.
